title.raw: 《留侯世家》 House of Marquis of Liu

sentences.zh: 留侯張良者，其先韓人也。

translations.literal: The Marquis of Liu Zhang Liang was originally from the state of Han.

sentences.zh: 大父開地，相韓昭侯、宣惠王、襄哀王。

translations.literal: His grandfather Kai Di served as chancellor to Han kings Zhao Hou, Xuan Hui Wang, and Xiang Ai Wang.

sentences.zh: 父平，相釐王、悼惠王。

translations.literal: His father Ping served as chancellor to Xi Wang and Dao Hui Wang.

sentences.zh: 悼惠王二十三年，平卒。

translations.literal: In Dao Hui Wang year 23, Ping died.

sentences.zh: 卒二十歲，秦滅韓。

translations.literal: Twenty years after his death, Qin destroyed Han.

sentences.zh: 良年少，未宦事韓。

translations.literal: Liang was young and had not yet taken office to serve Han.

sentences.zh: 韓破，良家僮三百人，弟死不葬，悉以家財求客刺秦王，為韓報仇，以大父、父五世相韓故。

translations.literal: When Han was destroyed, Liang had three hundred household slaves, his younger brother died unburied, he used all his family wealth to hire assassins to stab the Qin king, to avenge Han, because his grandfather and father had served as chancellors of Han for five generations.

The Marquis of Liu Zhang Liang was originally from the state of Han. His grandfather Kai Di served as chancellor to Han kings Zhao Hou, Xuan Hui Wang, and Xiang Ai Wang. His father Ping served as chancellor to Xi Wang and Dao Hui Wang. In Dao Hui Wang year 23, Ping died. Twenty years after his death, Qin destroyed Han. Liang was young and had not yet taken office to serve Han. When Han was destroyed, Liang had three hundred household slaves, his younger brother died unburied, he used all his family wealth to hire assassins to stab the Qin king, to avenge Han, because his grandfather and father had served as chancellors of Han for five generations.

sentences.zh: 良嘗學禮淮陽。

translations.literal: Liang once studied ritual in Huaiyang.

sentences.zh: 東見倉海君。

translations.literal: He went east to see Lord Cang Hai.

sentences.zh: 得力士，為鐵椎重百二十斤。

translations.literal: He obtained a strongman and had an iron mace made weighing 120 jin.

sentences.zh: 秦皇帝東游，良與客狙擊秦皇帝博浪沙中，誤中副車。

translations.literal: When the Qin emperor traveled east, Liang and his companions ambushed the Qin emperor at Bo Lang Sha, but mistakenly hit the escort carriage.

sentences.zh: 秦皇帝大怒，大索天下，求賊甚急，為張良故也。

translations.literal: The Qin emperor was greatly angered, conducted a great search throughout the realm, urgently seeking the assassins, all because of Zhang Liang.

sentences.zh: 良乃更名姓，亡匿下邳。

translations.literal: Liang then changed his name and surname, fled and hid in Xiapi.

Liang once studied ritual in Huaiyang. He went east to see Lord Cang Hai. He obtained a strongman and had an iron mace made weighing 120 jin. When the Qin emperor traveled east, Liang and his companions ambushed the Qin emperor at Bo Lang Sha, but mistakenly hit the escort carriage. The Qin emperor was greatly angered, conducted a great search throughout the realm, urgently seeking the assassins, all because of Zhang Liang. Liang then changed his name and surname, fled and hid in Xiapi.

sentences.zh: 良嘗閒從容步游下邳圯上，有一老父，衣褐，至良所，直墮其履圯下，顧謂良曰：「孺子，下取履！」

translations.literal: Liang once idly strolled leisurely on the bridge at Xiapi, when an old man in coarse clothing came to where Liang was, directly dropped his shoe down into the bridge, turned and told Liang: 'Young man, go down and get my shoe!'

sentences.zh: 良鄂然，欲毆之。

translations.literal: Liang was astonished and wanted to beat him.

sentences.zh: 為其老，彊忍，下取履。

translations.literal: Because he was old, he forcibly endured it and went down to get the shoe.

sentences.zh: 父曰：「履我！」

translations.literal: The old man said: 'Put it on me!'

sentences.zh: 良業為取履，因長跪履之。

translations.literal: Liang having already gotten the shoe, knelt straight and put it on him.

sentences.zh: 父以足受，笑而去。

translations.literal: The old man accepted it with his foot, laughed and left.

sentences.zh: 良殊大驚，隨目之。

translations.literal: Liang was extremely astonished and followed him with his eyes.

sentences.zh: 父去里所，復還，曰：「孺子可教矣。

translations.literal: The old man had gone about a li when he returned, saying: 'Young man can be taught.

sentences.zh: 後五日平明，與我會此。」

translations.literal: In five days at dawn, meet me here.'

sentences.zh: 良因怪之，跪曰：「諾。」

translations.literal: Liang was puzzled by this and knelt, saying: 'Yes.'

sentences.zh: 五日平明，良往。

translations.literal: In five days at dawn, Liang went.

sentences.zh: 父已先在，怒曰：「與老人期，後，何也？」

translations.literal: The old man was already there first, angry, saying: 'Meeting with an old man, being late—why?'

sentences.zh: 去，曰：「後五日早會。」

translations.literal: He left, saying: 'In five days come early.'

sentences.zh: 五日雞鳴，良往。

translations.literal: In five days at cockcrow, Liang went.

sentences.zh: 父又先在，復怒曰：「後，何也？」

translations.literal: The old man was there first again, again angry, saying: 'Late—why?'

sentences.zh: 去，曰：「後五日復早來。」

translations.literal: He left, saying: 'In five days come even earlier.'

sentences.zh: 五日，良夜未半往。

translations.literal: In five days, Liang went before midnight was half over.

sentences.zh: 有頃，父亦來，喜曰：「當如是。」

translations.literal: After a while, the old man also came, pleased, saying: 'It should be like this.'

sentences.zh: 出一編書，曰：「讀此則為王者師矣。

translations.literal: He took out a bound book, saying: 'Read this and you will be a king's teacher.

sentences.zh: 後十年興。

translations.literal: After ten years you will rise.

sentences.zh: 十三年孺子見我濟北，穀城山下黃石即我矣。」

translations.literal: In thirteen years the young man will see me in Jibei, under Gucheng Mountain—the yellow stone will be me.'

sentences.zh: 遂去，無他言，不復見。

translations.literal: He then left, with no other words, never seen again.

sentences.zh: 旦日視其書，乃太公兵法也。

translations.literal: The next day he examined the book—it was the military methods of Taigong.

sentences.zh: 良因異之，常習誦讀之。

translations.literal: Liang considered it extraordinary and constantly practiced and recited it.

Liang once idly strolled leisurely on the bridge at Xiapi, when an old man in coarse clothing came to where Liang was, directly dropped his shoe down into the bridge, turned and told Liang: 'Young man, go down and get my shoe!' Liang was astonished and wanted to beat him. Because he was old, he forcibly endured it and went down to get the shoe. The old man said: 'Put it on me!' Liang having already gotten the shoe, knelt straight and put it on him. The old man accepted it with his foot, laughed and left. Liang was extremely astonished and followed him with his eyes. The old man had gone about a li when he returned, saying: 'Young man can be taught. In five days at dawn, meet me here.' Liang was puzzled by this and knelt, saying: 'Yes.' In five days at dawn, Liang went. The old man was already there first, angry, saying: 'Meeting with an old man, being late—why?' He left, saying: 'In five days come early.' In five days at cockcrow, Liang went. The old man was there first again, again angry, saying: 'Late—why?' He left, saying: 'In five days come even earlier.' In five days, Liang went before midnight was half over. After a while, the old man also came, pleased, saying: 'It should be like this.' He took out a bound book, saying: 'Read this and you will be a king's teacher. After ten years you will rise. In thirteen years the young man will see me in Jibei, under Gucheng Mountain—the yellow stone will be me.' He then left, with no other words, never seen again. The next day he examined the book—it was the military methods of Taigong. Liang considered it extraordinary and constantly practiced and recited it.

sentences.zh: 居下邳，為任俠。

translations.literal: He lived in Xiapi and became a knight-errant.

sentences.zh: 項伯常殺人，從良匿。

translations.literal: Xiang Bo often killed people and hid with Liang.
He lived in Xiapi and became a knight-errant. Xiang Bo often killed people and hid with Liang.

sentences.zh: 後十年，陳涉等起兵，良亦聚少年百餘人。

translations.literal: Ten years later, Chen She and others raised troops, Liang also gathered over a hundred youths.

sentences.zh: 景駒自立為楚假王，在留。

translations.literal: Jing Ju established himself as acting king of Chu in Liu.

sentences.zh: 良欲往從之，道還沛公。

translations.literal: Liang wished to go follow him, but on the way encountered Duke Pei.

sentences.zh: 沛公將數千人，略地下邳西，遂屬焉。

translations.literal: Duke Pei led several thousand men, was raiding west of Xiapi, so Liang attached himself to him.

sentences.zh: 沛公拜良為廄將。

translations.literal: Duke Pei appointed Liang as stable master.

sentences.zh: 良數以太公兵法說沛公，沛公善之，常用其策。

translations.literal: Liang frequently explained Taigong's military methods to Duke Pei, Duke Pei liked them and often used his strategies.

sentences.zh: 良為他人者，皆不省。

translations.literal: When Liang explained to others, they all did not understand.

sentences.zh: 良曰：「沛公殆天授。」

translations.literal: Liang said: 'Duke Pei is probably heaven-sent.'

sentences.zh: 故遂從之，不去見景駒。

translations.literal: Therefore he followed him and did not go see Jing Ju.

Ten years later, Chen She and others raised troops, Liang also gathered over a hundred youths. Jing Ju established himself as acting king of Chu in Liu. Liang wished to go follow him, but on the way encountered Duke Pei. Duke Pei led several thousand men, was raiding west of Xiapi, so Liang attached himself to him. Duke Pei appointed Liang as stable master. Liang frequently explained Taigong's military methods to Duke Pei, Duke Pei liked them and often used his strategies. When Liang explained to others, they all did not understand. Liang said: 'Duke Pei is probably heaven-sent.' Therefore he followed him and did not go see Jing Ju.

sentences.zh: 及沛公之薛，見項梁。

translations.literal: When Duke Pei went to Xue, he saw Xiang Liang.

sentences.zh: 項梁立楚懷王。

translations.literal: Xiang Liang established King Huai of Chu.

sentences.zh: 良乃說項梁曰：「君已立楚後，而韓諸公子橫陽君成賢，可立為王，益樹黨。」

translations.literal: Liang then advised Xiang Liang: 'You have already established the Chu successor, but among the Han princes Lord Hengyang Cheng Xian can be established as king, to further build alliances.'

sentences.zh: 項梁使良求韓成，立以為韓王。

translations.literal: Xiang Liang sent Liang to seek Han Cheng, establishing him as King of Han.

sentences.zh: 以良為韓申徒，與韓王將千餘人西略韓地，得數城，秦輒復取之，往來為游兵潁川。

translations.literal: He appointed Liang as Han envoy, with the King of Han leading over a thousand men raiding Han territory to the west, capturing several cities, but Qin always recaptured them, going back and forth as roaming troops in Yingchuan.

When Duke Pei went to Xue, he saw Xiang Liang. Xiang Liang established King Huai of Chu. Liang then advised Xiang Liang: 'You have already established the Chu successor, but among the Han princes Lord Hengyang Cheng Xian can be established as king, to further build alliances.' Xiang Liang sent Liang to seek Han Cheng, establishing him as King of Han. He appointed Liang as Han envoy, with the King of Han leading over a thousand men raiding Han territory to the west, capturing several cities, but Qin always recaptured them, going back and forth as roaming troops in Yingchuan.

sentences.zh: 沛公之從雒陽南出轘轅，良引兵從沛公，下韓十餘城，擊破楊熊軍。

translations.literal: When Duke Pei came from Luoyang south out of Xuan Yuan, Liang led troops following Duke Pei, capturing over ten Han cities, defeating Yang Xiong's army.

sentences.zh: 沛公乃令韓王成留守陽翟，與良俱南，攻下宛，西入武關。

translations.literal: Duke Pei then ordered King Han Cheng to remain guarding Yangdi, and went south with Liang, attacking and capturing Wan, entering Wu Pass to the west.

sentences.zh: 沛公欲以兵二萬人擊秦嶢下軍，良說曰：「秦兵尚彊，未可輕。

translations.literal: Duke Pei wished to use 20,000 troops to attack the Qin army at Yao Pass, Liang advised: 'Qin troops are still strong, cannot be taken lightly.

sentences.zh: 臣聞其將屠者子，賈豎易動以利。

translations.literal: Your servant has heard their general is a butcher's son, a merchant lackey easily moved by profit.

sentences.zh: 願沛公且留壁，使人先行，為五萬人具食，益為張旗幟諸山上，為疑兵，令酈食其持重寶啗秦將。」

translations.literal: I wish Duke Pei would for now stay encamped, send people ahead to prepare provisions for 50,000 men, moreover place banners and flags on the various mountains as feigned troops, command Li Yiji to hold heavy treasures to bribe the Qin general.'

sentences.zh: 秦將果畔，欲連和俱西襲咸陽，沛公欲聽之。

translations.literal: The Qin general indeed defected, wishing to ally and together attack Xianyang to the west, Duke Pei wished to listen to him.

sentences.zh: 良曰：「此獨其將欲叛耳，恐士卒不從。

translations.literal: Liang said: 'This is only their general wishing to rebel, I fear the soldiers will not follow.

sentences.zh: 不從必危，不如因其解擊之。」

translations.literal: If they do not follow it will certainly be dangerous, better to take advantage of their relaxation to attack them.'

sentences.zh: 沛公乃引兵擊秦軍，大破之。

translations.literal: Duke Pei then led troops to attack the Qin army, greatly defeating them.

sentences.zh: （遂）［逐］北至藍田，再戰，秦兵竟敗。

translations.literal: Pursued north to Lantian, fought again, Qin troops utterly defeated.

sentences.zh: 遂至咸陽，秦王子嬰降沛公。

translations.literal: Thus reached Xianyang, Qin prince Zi Ying surrendered to Duke Pei.

When Duke Pei came from Luoyang south out of Xuan Yuan, Liang led troops following Duke Pei, capturing over ten Han cities, defeating Yang Xiong's army. Duke Pei then ordered King Han Cheng to remain guarding Yangdi, and went south with Liang, attacking and capturing Wan, entering Wu Pass to the west. Duke Pei wished to use 20,000 troops to attack the Qin army at Yao Pass, Liang advised: 'Qin troops are still strong, cannot be taken lightly. Your servant has heard their general is a butcher's son, a merchant lackey easily moved by profit. I wish Duke Pei would for now stay encamped, send people ahead to prepare provisions for 50,000 men, moreover place banners and flags on the various mountains as feigned troops, command Li Yiji to hold heavy treasures to bribe the Qin general.' The Qin general indeed defected, wishing to ally and together attack Xianyang to the west, Duke Pei wished to listen to him. Liang said: 'This is only their general wishing to rebel, I fear the soldiers will not follow. If they do not follow it will certainly be dangerous, better to take advantage of their relaxation to attack them.' Duke Pei then led troops to attack the Qin army, greatly defeating them. Pursued north to Lantian, fought again, Qin troops utterly defeated. Thus reached Xianyang, Qin prince Zi Ying surrendered to Duke Pei.

sentences.zh: 沛公入秦宮，宮室帷帳狗馬重寶婦女以千數，意欲留居之。

translations.literal: Duke Pei entered the Qin palace, palaces and chambers, curtains and canopies, dogs and horses, heavy treasures and women numbered in the thousands, he intended to stay and live there.

sentences.zh: 樊噲諫沛公出舍，沛公不聽。

translations.literal: Fan Kuai remonstrated Duke Pei to leave the palace, Duke Pei would not listen.

sentences.zh: 良曰：「夫秦為無道，故沛公得至此。

translations.literal: Liang said: 'Qin was without the Way, therefore Duke Pei was able to reach here.

sentences.zh: 夫為天下除殘賊，宜縞素為資。

translations.literal: To eliminate cruel tyrants for the realm, one should take plain silk as provision.

sentences.zh: 今始入秦，即安其樂，此所謂『助桀為虐』。

translations.literal: Now just entering Qin and enjoying its pleasures—this is called 'helping Jie be tyrannical'.

sentences.zh: 且『忠言逆耳利於行，毒藥苦口利於病』，願沛公聽樊噲言。」

translations.literal: Moreover 'loyal words grate on the ear but benefit conduct, bitter medicine hurts the mouth but benefits the illness'—I wish Duke Pei would listen to Fan Kuai's words.'

sentences.zh: 沛公乃還軍霸上。

translations.literal: Duke Pei then returned his army to Bashang.

Duke Pei entered the Qin palace, palaces and chambers, curtains and canopies, dogs and horses, heavy treasures and women numbered in the thousands, he intended to stay and live there. Fan Kuai remonstrated Duke Pei to leave the palace, Duke Pei would not listen. Liang said: 'Qin was without the Way, therefore Duke Pei was able to reach here. To eliminate cruel tyrants for the realm, one should take plain silk as provision. Now just entering Qin and enjoying its pleasures—this is called 'helping Jie be tyrannical'. Moreover 'loyal words grate on the ear but benefit conduct, bitter medicine hurts the mouth but benefits the illness'—I wish Duke Pei would listen to Fan Kuai's words.' Duke Pei then returned his army to Bashang.

sentences.zh: 項羽至鴻門下，欲擊沛公，項伯乃夜馳入沛公軍，私見張良，欲與俱去。

translations.literal: Xiang Yu arrived at Hongmen, wishing to attack Duke Pei, Xiang Bo then galloped into Duke Pei's army at night, privately saw Zhang Liang, wishing to leave with him.

sentences.zh: 良曰：「臣為韓王送沛公，今事有急，亡去不義。」

translations.literal: Liang said: 'Your servant escorted Duke Pei for the King of Han, now affairs are urgent, fleeing would be unrighteous.'

sentences.zh: 乃具以語沛公。

translations.literal: He fully told Duke Pei.

sentences.zh: 沛公大驚，曰：「為將奈何？」

translations.literal: Duke Pei was greatly alarmed, said: 'What to do about commanding?'

sentences.zh: 良曰：「沛公誠欲倍項羽邪？」

translations.literal: Liang said: 'Does Duke Pei truly wish to betray Xiang Yu?'

sentences.zh: 沛公曰：「鯫生教我距關無內諸侯，秦地可盡王，故聽之。」

translations.literal: Duke Pei said: 'The petty man taught me to close the passes and not let in the feudal lords, the Qin lands could all be made kingdoms, therefore I listened.'

sentences.zh: 良曰：「沛公自度能卻項羽乎？」

translations.literal: Liang said: 'Duke Pei yourself assess—can you repel Xiang Yu?'

sentences.zh: 沛公默然良久，曰：「固不能也。

translations.literal: Duke Pei was silent for a long time, said: 'Certainly cannot.

sentences.zh: 今為奈何？」

translations.literal: Now what to do?'

sentences.zh: 良乃固要項伯。

translations.literal: Liang then firmly detained Xiang Bo.

sentences.zh: 項伯見沛公。

translations.literal: Xiang Bo saw Duke Pei.

sentences.zh: 沛公與飲為壽，結賓婚。

translations.literal: Duke Pei drank toasts with him and formed marriage ties.

sentences.zh: 令項伯具言沛公不敢倍項羽，所以距關者，備他盜也。

translations.literal: He commanded Xiang Bo to fully explain that Duke Pei dared not betray Xiang Yu, the reason for closing the passes was to guard against other bandits.

sentences.zh: 及見項羽後解，語在項羽事中。

translations.literal: When he later saw Xiang Yu the misunderstanding was resolved—the account is in Xiang Yu's affairs.

Xiang Yu arrived at Hongmen, wishing to attack Duke Pei, Xiang Bo then galloped into Duke Pei's army at night, privately saw Zhang Liang, wishing to leave with him. Liang said: 'Your servant escorted Duke Pei for the King of Han, now affairs are urgent, fleeing would be unrighteous.' He fully told Duke Pei. Duke Pei was greatly alarmed, said: 'What to do about commanding?' Liang said: 'Does Duke Pei truly wish to betray Xiang Yu?' Duke Pei said: 'The petty man taught me to close the passes and not let in the feudal lords, the Qin lands could all be made kingdoms, therefore I listened.' Liang said: 'Duke Pei yourself assess—can you repel Xiang Yu?' Duke Pei was silent for a long time, said: 'Certainly cannot. Now what to do?' Liang then firmly detained Xiang Bo. Xiang Bo saw Duke Pei. Duke Pei drank toasts with him and formed marriage ties. He commanded Xiang Bo to fully explain that Duke Pei dared not betray Xiang Yu, the reason for closing the passes was to guard against other bandits. When he later saw Xiang Yu the misunderstanding was resolved—the account is in Xiang Yu's affairs.

sentences.zh: 漢元年正月，沛公為漢王，王巴蜀。

translations.literal: Han year 1 first month, Duke Pei became King of Han, ruling Bashu.

sentences.zh: 漢王賜良金百鎰，珠二斗，良具以獻項伯。

translations.literal: The King of Han granted Liang 100 yi of gold, two dou of pearls, Liang fully presented them to Xiang Bo.

sentences.zh: 漢王亦因令良厚遺項伯，使請漢中地。

translations.literal: The King of Han also commanded Liang to generously send gifts to Xiang Bo, to request Hanzhong territory.

sentences.zh: 項王乃許之，遂得漢中地。

translations.literal: Xiang Wang then permitted it, thus obtained Hanzhong territory.

sentences.zh: 漢王之國，良送至襃中，遣良歸韓。

translations.literal: When the King of Han went to his state, Liang escorted him to Baozhong, sent Liang back to Han.

sentences.zh: 良因說漢王曰：「王何不燒絕所過棧道，示天下無還心，以固項王意。」

translations.literal: Liang then advised the King of Han: 'Why doesn't your majesty burn and destroy the plank roads you pass through, showing the realm you have no intention of returning, to strengthen Xiang Wang's confidence.'

sentences.zh: 乃使良還。

translations.literal: He then sent Liang back.

sentences.zh: 行，燒絕棧道。

translations.literal: On the way, he burned and destroyed the plank roads.

Han year 1 first month, Duke Pei became King of Han, ruling Bashu. The King of Han granted Liang 100 yi of gold, two dou of pearls, Liang fully presented them to Xiang Bo. The King of Han also commanded Liang to generously send gifts to Xiang Bo, to request Hanzhong territory. Xiang Wang then permitted it, thus obtained Hanzhong territory. When the King of Han went to his state, Liang escorted him to Baozhong, sent Liang back to Han. Liang then advised the King of Han: 'Why doesn't your majesty burn and destroy the plank roads you pass through, showing the realm you have no intention of returning, to strengthen Xiang Wang's confidence.' He then sent Liang back. On the way, he burned and destroyed the plank roads.

sentences.zh: 良至韓，韓王成以良從漢王故，項王不遣成之國，從與俱東。

translations.literal: Liang arrived in Han, King Han Cheng because Liang had followed the King of Han, Xiang Wang would not send Cheng to his state, had him follow and go east together.

sentences.zh: 良說項王曰：「漢王燒絕棧道，無還心矣。」

translations.literal: Liang advised Xiang Wang: 'The King of Han has burned the plank roads, he has no intention of returning.'

sentences.zh: 乃以齊王田榮反，書告項王。

translations.literal: He then used the matter of King Qi Tian Rong rebelling to write and inform Xiang Wang.

sentences.zh: 項王以此無西憂漢心，而發兵北擊齊。

translations.literal: Xiang Wang because of this had no western worries about Han's intentions, and dispatched troops north to attack Qi.

Liang arrived in Han, King Han Cheng because Liang had followed the King of Han, Xiang Wang would not send Cheng to his state, had him follow and go east together. Liang advised Xiang Wang: 'The King of Han has burned the plank roads, he has no intention of returning.' He then used the matter of King Qi Tian Rong rebelling to write and inform Xiang Wang. Xiang Wang because of this had no western worries about Han's intentions, and dispatched troops north to attack Qi.

sentences.zh: 項王竟不肯遣韓王，乃以為侯，又殺之彭城。

translations.literal: Xiang Wang ultimately refused to send the King of Han, made him a marquis instead, then killed him at Pengcheng.

translations.literal: Yet those who ultimately broke Chu were these three men's strength.

Xiang Wang ultimately refused to send the King of Han, made him a marquis instead, then killed him at Pengcheng. Liang fled, secretly traveled back to the King of Han, the King of Han had also returned and pacified the Three Qins. Again appointed Liang as Marquis of Chengxin, following east to attack Chu. Arrived at Pengcheng, Han was defeated and returned. Arrived at Xiayi, the King of Han dismounted and sat on his saddle asking: 'I wish to abandon everything east of the passes—who can share merit with me?' Liang advanced and said: 'King Jiu Jiang Ying Bu is a fierce Chu general, has a grudge with Xiang Wang; Peng Yue is rebelling in Liang territory with King Qi Tian Rong: these two can be urgently employed. Among the King of Han's generals, only Han Xin can be entrusted with great matters, to hold one front. If you wish to abandon it, abandon it to these three men, then Chu can be broken.' The King of Han then sent Sui He to persuade King Jiu Jiang Bu, and sent people to contact Peng Yue. When King Wei Bao rebelled, he had Han Xin lead troops to attack him, thus raising Yan, Dai, Qi, and Zhao. Yet those who ultimately broke Chu were these three men's strength.

translations.literal: Han year 3, Xiang Yu urgently besieged the King of Han at Xingyang, the King of Han was fearful and worried, consulted with Li Yiji about weakening Chu's power.

sentences.zh: 食其曰：「昔湯伐桀，封其後於杞。

translations.literal: Li Yiji said: 'In ancient times Tang attacked Jie and enfeoffed his descendants in Qi.

sentences.zh: 武王伐紂，封其後於宋。

translations.literal: King Wu attacked Zhou and enfeoffed his descendants in Song.

sentences.zh: 今秦失德棄義，侵伐諸侯社稷，滅六國之後，使無立錐之地。

translations.literal: Now Qin lost virtue and abandoned righteousness, invaded the feudal lords' altars of soil and grain, extinguished the six states' descendants, leaving them with no place to stand a spike.

sentences.zh: 陛下誠能復立六國後世，畢已受印，此其君臣百姓必皆戴陛下之德，莫不鄉風慕義，願為臣妾。

translations.literal: If your majesty can truly restore the six states' descendants, once they have all received seals, their lords and ministers and common people will certainly all wear your majesty's virtue, none will not turn toward the wind and admire righteousness, wishing to be subjects and concubines.

sentences.zh: 德義已行，陛下南鄉稱霸，楚必斂衽而朝。」

translations.literal: Once virtue and righteousness are practiced, your majesty facing south will proclaim hegemony, Chu will certainly gather robes and come to court.'

sentences.zh: 漢王曰：「善。

translations.literal: The King of Han said: 'Good.

sentences.zh: 趣刻印，先生因行佩之矣。」

translations.literal: Hurry and carve the seals, sir go and carry them.'

Han year 3, Xiang Yu urgently besieged the King of Han at Xingyang, the King of Han was fearful and worried, consulted with Li Yiji about weakening Chu's power. Li Yiji said: 'In ancient times Tang attacked Jie and enfeoffed his descendants in Qi. King Wu attacked Zhou and enfeoffed his descendants in Song. Now Qin lost virtue and abandoned righteousness, invaded the feudal lords' altars of soil and grain, extinguished the six states' descendants, leaving them with no place to stand a spike. If your majesty can truly restore the six states' descendants, once they have all received seals, their lords and ministers and common people will certainly all wear your majesty's virtue, none will not turn toward the wind and admire righteousness, wishing to be subjects and concubines. Once virtue and righteousness are practiced, your majesty facing south will proclaim hegemony, Chu will certainly gather robes and come to court.' The King of Han said: 'Good. Hurry and carve the seals, sir go and carry them.'

sentences.zh: 食其未行，張良從外來謁。

translations.literal: Li Yiji had not yet departed when Zhang Liang came from outside to greet.

sentences.zh: 漢王方食，曰：「子房前！

translations.literal: The King of Han was eating, said: 'Zifang come forward!

sentences.zh: 客有為我計橈楚權者。」

translations.literal: There is a guest who has planned for me to weaken Chu's power.'

sentences.zh: 其以酈生語告，曰：「於子房何如？」

translations.literal: He told him Li Yiji's words, said: 'What does Zifang think of this?'

sentences.zh: 良曰：「誰為陛下畫此計者？

translations.literal: Liang said: 'Who devised this plan for your majesty?

sentences.zh: 陛下事去矣。」

translations.literal: Your majesty's affairs are finished.'

sentences.zh: 漢王曰：「何哉？」

translations.literal: The King of Han said: 'Why?'

sentences.zh: 張良對曰：「臣請藉前箸為大王籌之。」

translations.literal: Zhang Liang replied: 'Your servant requests to borrow the eating sticks in front to plan for the great king.'

sentences.zh: 曰：「昔者湯伐桀而封其後於杞者，度能制桀之死命也。

translations.literal: He said: 'In ancient times Tang attacked Jie and enfeoffed his descendants in Qi because he assessed he could control Jie's fate.

sentences.zh: 今陛下能制項籍之死命乎？」

translations.literal: Now can your majesty control Xiang Ji's fate?'

sentences.zh: 曰：「未能也。」

translations.literal: Said: 'Cannot.'

sentences.zh: 「其不可一也。

translations.literal: 'This is the first reason it cannot be done.

sentences.zh: 武王伐紂封其後於宋者，度能得紂之頭也。

translations.literal: King Wu attacked Zhou and enfeoffed his descendants in Song because he assessed he could obtain Zhou's head.

sentences.zh: 今陛下能得項籍之頭乎？」

translations.literal: Now can your majesty obtain Xiang Ji's head?'

sentences.zh: 曰：「未能也。」

translations.literal: Said: 'Cannot.'

sentences.zh: 「其不可二也。

translations.literal: 'This is the second reason it cannot be done.

sentences.zh: 武王入殷，表商容之閭，釋箕子之拘，封比干之墓。

translations.literal: When King Wu entered Yin, he honored Shang Rong's gate, released Ji Zi's imprisonment, sealed Bi Gan's grave.

sentences.zh: 今陛下能封聖人之墓，表賢者之閭，式智者之門乎？」

translations.literal: Now can your majesty seal sages' graves, honor worthies' gates, bow to the wise's doors?'

sentences.zh: 曰：「未能也。」

translations.literal: Said: 'Cannot.'

sentences.zh: 「其不可三也。

translations.literal: 'This is the third reason it cannot be done.

sentences.zh: 發鉅橋之粟，散鹿臺之錢，以賜貧窮。

translations.literal: He opened Ju Qiao's granaries, scattered Lu Tai's money, to grant to the poor.

sentences.zh: 今陛下能散府庫以賜貧窮乎？」

translations.literal: Now can your majesty scatter the treasuries to grant to the poor?'

sentences.zh: 曰：「未能也。」

translations.literal: Said: 'Cannot.'

sentences.zh: 「其不可四矣。

translations.literal: 'This is the fourth reason it cannot be done.

sentences.zh: 殷事已畢，偃革為軒，倒置干戈，覆以虎皮，以示天下不復用兵。

translations.literal: When Yin affairs were finished, he laid aside armor for carriages, placed weapons upside down, covered them with tiger skins, to show the realm no longer used troops.

sentences.zh: 今陛下能偃武行文，不復用兵乎？」

translations.literal: Now can your majesty lay aside arms and practice civility, no longer use troops?'

sentences.zh: 曰：「未能也。」

translations.literal: Said: 'Cannot.'

sentences.zh: 「其不可五矣。

translations.literal: 'This is the fifth reason it cannot be done.

sentences.zh: 休馬華山之陽，示以無所為。

translations.literal: He rested horses on Mount Hua's north slope, showing he had nothing to do.

sentences.zh: 今陛下能休馬無所用乎？」

translations.literal: Now can your majesty rest horses with nothing to use them for?'

sentences.zh: 曰：「未能也。」

translations.literal: Said: 'Cannot.'

sentences.zh: 「其不可六矣。

translations.literal: 'This is the sixth reason it cannot be done.'

translations.literal: He released oxen in Taolin's shade, to show no more transporting provisions.

sentences.zh: 今陛下能放牛不復輸積乎？」

translations.literal: Now can your majesty release oxen and no more transport provisions?'

sentences.zh: 曰：「未能也。」

translations.literal: Said: 'Cannot.'

sentences.zh: 「其不可七矣。

translations.literal: 'This is the seventh reason it cannot be done.

sentences.zh: 且天下游士離其親戚，棄墳墓，去故舊，從陛下游者，徒欲日夜望咫尺之地。

translations.literal: Moreover, the wandering scholars of the realm have left their relatives, abandoned their graves, departed from old acquaintances, following your majesty—these all desire day and night to hope for a foot of land.

sentences.zh: 今復六國，立韓、魏、燕、趙、齊、楚之後，天下游士各歸事其主，從其親戚，反其故舊墳墓，陛下與誰取天下乎？

translations.literal: Now if the six states are restored, establishing the descendants of Han, Wei, Yan, Zhao, Qi, and Chu, the wandering scholars of the realm will each return to serve their lords, follow their relatives, return to their old acquaintances' graves— with whom will your majesty take the realm?

sentences.zh: 其不可八矣。

translations.literal: This is the eighth reason it cannot be done.

sentences.zh: 且夫楚唯無彊，六國立者復橈而從之，陛下焉得而臣之？

translations.literal: Moreover, Chu is the only one without strength—if the six states are established, they will again bend and follow Chu, how can your majesty make them subjects?

sentences.zh: 誠用客之謀，陛下事去矣。」

Li Yiji had not yet departed when Zhang Liang came from outside to greet. The King of Han was eating, said: 'Zifang come forward! There is a guest who has planned for me to weaken Chu's power.' He told him Li Yiji's words, said: 'What does Zifang think of this?' Liang said: 'Who devised this plan for your majesty? Your majesty's affairs are finished.' The King of Han said: 'Why?' Zhang Liang replied: 'Your servant requests to borrow the eating sticks in front to plan for the great king.' He said: 'In ancient times Tang attacked Jie and enfeoffed his descendants in Qi because he assessed he could control Jie's fate. Now can your majesty control Xiang Ji's fate?' Said: 'Cannot.' 'This is the first reason it cannot be done. King Wu attacked Zhou and enfeoffed his descendants in Song because he assessed he could obtain Zhou's head. Now can your majesty obtain Xiang Ji's head?' Said: 'Cannot.' 'This is the second reason it cannot be done. When King Wu entered Yin, he honored Shang Rong's gate, released Ji Zi's imprisonment, sealed Bi Gan's grave. Now can your majesty seal sages' graves, honor worthies' gates, bow to the wise's doors?' Said: 'Cannot.' 'This is the third reason it cannot be done. He opened Ju Qiao's granaries, scattered Lu Tai's money, to grant to the poor. Now can your majesty scatter the treasuries to grant to the poor?' Said: 'Cannot.' 'This is the fourth reason it cannot be done. When Yin affairs were finished, he laid aside armor for carriages, placed weapons upside down, covered them with tiger skins, to show the realm no longer used troops. Now can your majesty lay aside arms and practice civility, no longer use troops?' Said: 'Cannot.' 'This is the fifth reason it cannot be done. He rested horses on Mount Hua's north slope, showing he had nothing to do. Now can your majesty rest horses with nothing to use them for?' Said: 'Cannot.' 'This is the sixth reason it cannot be done.' He released oxen in Taolin's shade, to show no more transporting provisions. Now can your majesty release oxen and no more transport provisions?' Said: 'Cannot.' 'This is the seventh reason it cannot be done. Moreover, the wandering scholars of the realm have left their relatives, abandoned their graves, departed from old acquaintances, following your majesty—these all desire day and night to hope for a foot of land. Now if the six states are restored, establishing the descendants of Han, Wei, Yan, Zhao, Qi, and Chu, the wandering scholars of the realm will each return to serve their lords, follow their relatives, return to their old acquaintances' graves— with whom will your majesty take the realm? This is the eighth reason it cannot be done. Moreover, Chu is the only one without strength—if the six states are established, they will again bend and follow Chu, how can your majesty make them subjects? If you truly use the guest's plan, your majesty's affairs are finished.' The King of Han stopped eating and spat out his food, cursed saying: 'Base Confucian, nearly ruined our public affairs!' Commanded to hurry and destroy the seals.

sentences.zh: 漢四年，韓信破齊而欲自立為齊王，漢王怒。

translations.literal: Han year 4, Han Xin defeated Qi and wished to establish himself as King of Qi, the King of Han was angry.

sentences.zh: 良未嘗有戰鬬功，高帝曰：「運籌策帷帳中，決勝千里外，子房功也。

translations.literal: Liang had never had battle merit, Gaozu said: 'Planning strategies within the tent, deciding victories a thousand li away— this is Zifang's merit.

sentences.zh: 自擇齊三萬戶。」

translations.literal: Choose for yourself 30,000 households from Qi.'

sentences.zh: 良曰：「始臣起下邳，與上會留，此天以臣授陛下。

translations.literal: Liang said: 'At first your servant rose from Xiapi, met the emperor at Liu—this was heaven granting your servant to the emperor.

sentences.zh: 陛下用臣計，幸而時中，臣願封留足矣，不敢當三萬戶。」

translations.literal: The emperor used your servant's plans, luckily they sometimes hit the mark, your servant wishes only to be enfeoffed in Liu, does not dare to receive 30,000 households.'

sentences.zh: 乃封張良為留侯，與蕭何等俱封。

translations.literal: Thus he enfeoffed Zhang Liang as Marquis of Liu, enfeoffed together with Xiao He and others.

Han year 6 first month, enfeoffed the meritorious officials. Liang had never had battle merit, Gaozu said: 'Planning strategies within the tent, deciding victories a thousand li away— this is Zifang's merit. Choose for yourself 30,000 households from Qi.' Liang said: 'At first your servant rose from Xiapi, met the emperor at Liu—this was heaven granting your servant to the emperor. The emperor used your servant's plans, luckily they sometimes hit the mark, your servant wishes only to be enfeoffed in Liu, does not dare to receive 30,000 households.' Thus he enfeoffed Zhang Liang as Marquis of Liu, enfeoffed together with Xiao He and others.

sentences.zh: ［六年］上已封大功臣二十餘人，其餘日夜爭功不決，未得行封。

translations.literal: [Year 6] The emperor had already enfeoffed over twenty great meritorious officials, the remainder day and night disputed merits undecided, could not carry out enfeoffments.

sentences.zh: 上在雒陽南宮，從複道望見諸將往往相與坐沙中語。

translations.literal: The emperor was in Luoyang's southern palace, from the elevated walkway saw the various generals often sitting together in the sand speaking.

sentences.zh: 上曰：「此何語？」

translations.literal: The emperor said: 'What are they speaking of?'

sentences.zh: 留侯曰：「陛下不知乎？

translations.literal: The Marquis of Liu said: 'Does your majesty not know?

sentences.zh: 此謀反耳。」

translations.literal: This is plotting rebellion.'

sentences.zh: 上曰：「天下屬安定，何故反乎？」

translations.literal: The emperor said: 'The realm is just now peaceful and stable, why rebel?'

sentences.zh: 留侯曰：「陛下起布衣，以此屬取天下，今陛下為天子，而所封皆蕭、曹故人所親愛，而所誅者皆生平所仇怨。

translations.literal: The Marquis of Liu said: 'Your majesty rose from commoner status, used these people to take the realm, now your majesty is Son of Heaven, but those enfeoffed are all Xiao and Cao's old friends and loved ones, while those executed are all lifelong enemies.

sentences.zh: 今軍吏計功，以天下不足遍封，此屬畏陛下不能盡封，恐又見疑平生過失及誅，故即相聚謀反耳。」

translations.literal: Now the military officers calculate merits, considering the realm insufficient to enfeoff all, these people fear your majesty cannot fully enfeoff them, fear they will again be suspected of lifelong faults and executed, thus they gather together to plot rebellion.'

sentences.zh: 上乃憂曰：「為之奈何？」

translations.literal: The emperor then worried, said: 'What to do about it?'

sentences.zh: 留侯曰：「上平生所憎，群臣所共知，誰最甚者？」

translations.literal: The Marquis of Liu said: 'Among those the emperor has always hated, whom the ministers all know—who is the most hated?'

sentences.zh: 上曰：「雍齒與我故，數嘗窘辱我。

translations.literal: The emperor said: 'Yong Chi and I are old acquaintances, several times he has distressed and humiliated me.

sentences.zh: 我欲殺之，為其功多，故不忍。」

translations.literal: I wished to kill him, but because his merit is great, I could not bear to.'

sentences.zh: 留侯曰：「今急先封雍齒以示群臣，群臣見雍齒封，則人人自堅矣。」

translations.literal: The Marquis of Liu said: 'Now urgently first enfeoff Yong Chi to show the ministers, when the ministers see Yong Chi enfeoffed, then each person will be self-assured.'

sentences.zh: 於是上乃置酒，封雍齒為什方侯，而急趣丞相、御史定功行封。

translations.literal: Thus the emperor set up wine, enfeoffed Yong Chi as Marquis of Shifang, and urgently urged the chancellor and superintendent to determine merits and carry out enfeoffments.

sentences.zh: 群臣罷酒，皆喜曰：「雍齒尚為侯，我屬無患矣。」

translations.literal: The ministers finished the wine, all rejoiced saying: 'Yong Chi is still made marquis, we have no worries.'

[Year 6] The emperor had already enfeoffed over twenty great meritorious officials, the remainder day and night disputed merits undecided, could not carry out enfeoffments. The emperor was in Luoyang's southern palace, from the elevated walkway saw the various generals often sitting together in the sand speaking. The emperor said: 'What are they speaking of?' The Marquis of Liu said: 'Does your majesty not know? This is plotting rebellion.' The emperor said: 'The realm is just now peaceful and stable, why rebel?' The Marquis of Liu said: 'Your majesty rose from commoner status, used these people to take the realm, now your majesty is Son of Heaven, but those enfeoffed are all Xiao and Cao's old friends and loved ones, while those executed are all lifelong enemies. Now the military officers calculate merits, considering the realm insufficient to enfeoff all, these people fear your majesty cannot fully enfeoff them, fear they will again be suspected of lifelong faults and executed, thus they gather together to plot rebellion.' The emperor then worried, said: 'What to do about it?' The Marquis of Liu said: 'Among those the emperor has always hated, whom the ministers all know—who is the most hated?' The emperor said: 'Yong Chi and I are old acquaintances, several times he has distressed and humiliated me. I wished to kill him, but because his merit is great, I could not bear to.' The Marquis of Liu said: 'Now urgently first enfeoff Yong Chi to show the ministers, when the ministers see Yong Chi enfeoffed, then each person will be self-assured.' Thus the emperor set up wine, enfeoffed Yong Chi as Marquis of Shifang, and urgently urged the chancellor and superintendent to determine merits and carry out enfeoffments. The ministers finished the wine, all rejoiced saying: 'Yong Chi is still made marquis, we have no worries.'

sentences.zh: 劉敬說高帝曰：「都關中。」

translations.literal: Liu Jing advised Gaozu: 'Establish the capital in Guanzhong.'

sentences.zh: 上疑之。

translations.literal: The emperor doubted it.

sentences.zh: 左右大臣皆山東人，多勸上都雒陽：「雒陽東有成皋，西有殽黽，倍河，向伊雒，其固亦足恃。」

translations.literal: The ministers around him were all Shandong people, many advised the emperor to establish capital in Luoyang: 'Luoyang east has Chenggao, west has Xiaomeng, with the Yellow River behind, facing Yi and Luo—its fortifications are also sufficient to rely on.'

sentences.zh: 留侯曰：「雒陽雖有此固，其中小，不過數百里，田地薄，四面受敵，此非用武之國也。

translations.literal: The Marquis of Liu said: 'Although Luoyang has these fortifications, within it is small, no more than several hundred li, the fields and soil are poor, four sides receive enemies—this is not a country for using arms.

sentences.zh: 夫關中左殽函，右隴蜀，沃野千里，南有巴蜀之饒，北有胡苑之利，阻三面而守，獨以一面東制諸侯。

translations.literal: Guanzhong has Xiao to the left, Han to the right, fertile plains a thousand li, south has Bashu's wealth, north has the Xiongnu's advantages, blocking three sides to defend, alone using one side east to control the feudal lords.

sentences.zh: 諸侯安定，河渭漕輓天下，西給京師；

translations.literal: When feudal lords are peaceful, Yellow River and Wei transport supplies for the realm, west supplying the capital;

sentences.zh: 諸侯有變，順流而下，足以委輸。

translations.literal: when feudal lords rebel, following the current down, sufficient for transporting supplies.

sentences.zh: 此所謂金城千里，天府之國也，劉敬說是也。」

translations.literal: This is called a golden city of a thousand li, a heavenly storehouse country—Liu Jing's words are correct.'

sentences.zh: 於是高帝即日駕，西都關中。

translations.literal: Thus Gaozu that day drove west, establishing the capital in Guanzhong.

Liu Jing advised Gaozu: 'Establish the capital in Guanzhong.' The emperor doubted it. The ministers around him were all Shandong people, many advised the emperor to establish capital in Luoyang: 'Luoyang east has Chenggao, west has Xiaomeng, with the Yellow River behind, facing Yi and Luo—its fortifications are also sufficient to rely on.' The Marquis of Liu said: 'Although Luoyang has these fortifications, within it is small, no more than several hundred li, the fields and soil are poor, four sides receive enemies—this is not a country for using arms. Guanzhong has Xiao to the left, Han to the right, fertile plains a thousand li, south has Bashu's wealth, north has the Xiongnu's advantages, blocking three sides to defend, alone using one side east to control the feudal lords. When feudal lords are peaceful, Yellow River and Wei transport supplies for the realm, west supplying the capital; when feudal lords rebel, following the current down, sufficient for transporting supplies. This is called a golden city of a thousand li, a heavenly storehouse country—Liu Jing's words are correct.' Thus Gaozu that day drove west, establishing the capital in Guanzhong.

sentences.zh: 留侯從入關。

translations.literal: The Marquis of Liu followed into the passes.

sentences.zh: 留侯性多病，即道引不食穀，杜門不出歲餘。

translations.literal: The Marquis of Liu by nature was often ill, thus practiced guiding and pulling exercises, did not eat grain, shut his door and did not go out for over a year.

The Marquis of Liu followed into the passes. The Marquis of Liu by nature was often ill, thus practiced guiding and pulling exercises, did not eat grain, shut his door and did not go out for over a year.

sentences.zh: 上欲廢太子，立戚夫人子趙王如意。

translations.literal: The emperor wished to depose the crown prince, establish Lady Qi's son King Zhao of You.

sentences.zh: 大臣多諫爭，未能得堅決者也。

translations.literal: Ministers many remonstrated and disputed, but could not obtain a firm decision.

sentences.zh: 呂后恐，不知所為。

translations.literal: Empress Lü was fearful, did not know what to do.

sentences.zh: 人或謂呂后曰：「留侯善畫計筴，上信用之。」

translations.literal: Someone told Empress Lü: 'The Marquis of Liu is skilled at planning strategies, the emperor trusts and employs him.'

sentences.zh: 呂后乃使建成侯呂澤劫留侯，曰：「君常為上謀臣，今上欲易太子，君安得高枕而臥乎？」

translations.literal: Empress Lü then sent Marquis Jiancheng Lü Ze to coerce the Marquis of Liu, saying: 'You have constantly been the emperor's planning minister, now the emperor wishes to change the crown prince—how can you lie high with pillow and sleep peacefully?'

sentences.zh: 留侯曰：「始上數在困急之中，幸用臣筴。

translations.literal: The Marquis of Liu said: 'At first the emperor was several times in dire straits, luckily used your servant's strategies.

sentences.zh: 今天下安定，以愛欲易太子，骨肉之間，雖臣等百餘人何益。」

translations.literal: Now the realm is peaceful and stable, to change the crown prince out of favoritism—in family matters, even if we ministers number over a hundred, what benefit?'

sentences.zh: 呂澤彊要曰：「為我畫計。」

translations.literal: Lü Ze strongly urged: 'Plan for me.'

sentences.zh: 留侯曰：「此難以口舌爭也。

translations.literal: The Marquis of Liu said: 'This cannot be disputed with words.

sentences.zh: 顧上有不能致者，天下有四人。

translations.literal: There are four people in the realm whom the emperor cannot summon.

sentences.zh: 四人者年老矣，皆以為上慢侮人，故逃匿山中，義不為漢臣。

translations.literal: These four people are old, all because they considered the emperor to slight and insult people, thus fled and hid in the mountains, righteously would not be Han ministers.

sentences.zh: 然上高此四人。

translations.literal: Yet the emperor esteems these four people.

sentences.zh: 今公誠能無愛金玉璧帛，令太子為書，卑辭安車，因使辯士固請，宜來。

translations.literal: Now if you can truly not spare gold, jade, walls, and silks, have the crown prince write a letter, humble words and comfortable carriage, moreover send eloquent officials to firmly request—they should come.

sentences.zh: 來，以為客，時時從入朝，令上見之，則必異而問之。

translations.literal: When they come, treat them as guests, have them frequently accompany into court, let the emperor see them, then he will certainly regard them unusually and question them.

sentences.zh: 問之，上知此四人賢，則一助也。」

translations.literal: When questioned, the emperor knowing these four are worthy, then it will be one help.'

sentences.zh: 於是呂后令呂澤使人奉太子書，卑辭厚禮，迎此四人。

translations.literal: Thus Empress Lü commanded Lü Ze to send people carrying the crown prince's letter, humble words and generous gifts, to welcome these four people.

sentences.zh: 四人至，客建成侯所。

translations.literal: The four people arrived, were guests at the Marquis of Jiancheng's residence.

The emperor wished to depose the crown prince, establish Lady Qi's son King Zhao of You. Ministers many remonstrated and disputed, but could not obtain a firm decision. Empress Lü was fearful, did not know what to do. Someone told Empress Lü: 'The Marquis of Liu is skilled at planning strategies, the emperor trusts and employs him.' Empress Lü then sent Marquis Jiancheng Lü Ze to coerce the Marquis of Liu, saying: 'You have constantly been the emperor's planning minister, now the emperor wishes to change the crown prince—how can you lie high with pillow and sleep peacefully?' The Marquis of Liu said: 'At first the emperor was several times in dire straits, luckily used your servant's strategies. Now the realm is peaceful and stable, to change the crown prince out of favoritism—in family matters, even if we ministers number over a hundred, what benefit?' Lü Ze strongly urged: 'Plan for me.' The Marquis of Liu said: 'This cannot be disputed with words. There are four people in the realm whom the emperor cannot summon. These four people are old, all because they considered the emperor to slight and insult people, thus fled and hid in the mountains, righteously would not be Han ministers. Yet the emperor esteems these four people. Now if you can truly not spare gold, jade, walls, and silks, have the crown prince write a letter, humble words and comfortable carriage, moreover send eloquent officials to firmly request—they should come. When they come, treat them as guests, have them frequently accompany into court, let the emperor see them, then he will certainly regard them unusually and question them. When questioned, the emperor knowing these four are worthy, then it will be one help.' Thus Empress Lü commanded Lü Ze to send people carrying the crown prince's letter, humble words and generous gifts, to welcome these four people. The four people arrived, were guests at the Marquis of Jiancheng's residence.

sentences.zh: 漢十一年，黥布反，上病，欲使太子將，往擊之。

translations.literal: Han year 11, Ying Bu rebelled, the emperor was ill, wished to have the crown prince lead troops, go attack him.

sentences.zh: 四人相謂曰：「凡來者，將以存太子。

translations.literal: The four people discussed among themselves: 'We came in general to preserve the crown prince.

sentences.zh: 太子將兵，事危矣。」

translations.literal: If the crown prince leads troops, the matter is dangerous.'

sentences.zh: 乃說建成侯曰：「太子將兵，有功則位不益太子；

translations.literal: Thus they advised the Marquis of Jiancheng: 'If the crown prince leads troops and has merit, his position will not benefit the crown prince;

sentences.zh: 無功還，則從此受禍矣。

translations.literal: if no merit and returns, then from this he will receive disaster.

sentences.zh: 且太子所與俱諸將，皆嘗與上定天下梟將也，今使太子將之，此無異使羊將狼也，皆不肯為盡力，其無功必矣。

translations.literal: Moreover the various generals accompanying the crown prince have all once been fierce generals who pacified the realm with the emperor, now to have the crown prince command them—this is no different from making a sheep lead wolves, they will all be unwilling to exert full effort, it will certainly be no merit.

sentences.zh: 臣聞『母愛者子抱』，今戚夫人日夜待御，趙王如意常抱居前，上曰『終不使不肖子居愛子之上』，明乎其代太子位必矣。

translations.literal: Your servant has heard 'a mother who loves her child embraces him', now Lady Qi serves day and night, King Zhao You Yi is constantly held in front, the emperor says 'I will never let an unworthy son be placed above a beloved son', clearly his replacing the crown prince's position is certain.

sentences.zh: 君何不急請呂后承間為上泣言：『黥布，天下猛將也，善用兵，今諸將皆陛下故等夷，乃令太子將此屬，無異使羊將狼，莫肯為用，且使布聞之，則鼓行而西耳。

translations.literal: Why don't you urgently request Empress Lü to seize the opportunity and weepingly tell the emperor: 'Ying Bu is a fierce general of the realm, skilled in using troops, now the various generals are all your majesty's former equals, to command the crown prince to lead these people is no different from making a sheep lead wolves, none will be willing to be employed, moreover if Bu hears of it, he will drum and advance west.

sentences.zh: 上雖病，彊載輜車，臥而護之，諸將不敢不盡力。

translations.literal: Although your majesty is ill, force yourself to ride in the baggage cart, lie down and supervise them, the various generals will dare not not exert full effort.

sentences.zh: 上雖苦，為妻子自彊。』」

translations.literal: Although your majesty suffers, for the sake of wife and children force yourself.'

sentences.zh: 於是呂澤立夜見呂后，呂后承間為上泣涕而言，如四人意。

translations.literal: Thus Lü Ze that night saw Empress Lü, Empress Lü seized the opportunity and weeping told the emperor, as the four people's intention.

sentences.zh: 上曰：「吾惟豎子固不足遣，而公自行耳。」

translations.literal: The emperor said: 'I only considered the brat certainly insufficient to send, so I must go myself.'

sentences.zh: 於是上自將兵而東，群臣居守，皆送至灞上。

translations.literal: Thus the emperor personally led troops east, the ministers remained to guard, all escorted to Bashang.

sentences.zh: 留侯病，自彊起，至曲郵，見上曰：「臣宜從，病甚。

translations.literal: The Marquis of Liu was ill, forced himself to rise, arrived at Quyü, saw the emperor and said: 'Your servant should follow, but illness is severe.

sentences.zh: 楚人剽疾，願上無與楚人爭鋒。」

translations.literal: Chu people are fierce and swift, I wish your majesty not to contend with Chu people at the spearpoint.'

sentences.zh: 因說上曰：「令太子為將軍，監關中兵。」

translations.literal: Thus he advised the emperor: 'Have the crown prince serve as general, oversee Guanzhong troops.'

sentences.zh: 上曰：「子房雖病，彊臥而傅太子。」

translations.literal: The emperor said: 'Zifang although ill, force yourself to lie down and instruct the crown prince.'

sentences.zh: 是時叔孫通為太傅，留侯行少傅事。

translations.literal: At this time Shu Sun Tong served as Grand Tutor, the Marquis of Liu performed Junior Tutor duties.

Han year 11, Ying Bu rebelled, the emperor was ill, wished to have the crown prince lead troops, go attack him. The four people discussed among themselves: 'We came in general to preserve the crown prince. If the crown prince leads troops, the matter is dangerous.' Thus they advised the Marquis of Jiancheng: 'If the crown prince leads troops and has merit, his position will not benefit the crown prince; if no merit and returns, then from this he will receive disaster. Moreover the various generals accompanying the crown prince have all once been fierce generals who pacified the realm with the emperor, now to have the crown prince command them—this is no different from making a sheep lead wolves, they will all be unwilling to exert full effort, it will certainly be no merit. Your servant has heard 'a mother who loves her child embraces him', now Lady Qi serves day and night, King Zhao You Yi is constantly held in front, the emperor says 'I will never let an unworthy son be placed above a beloved son', clearly his replacing the crown prince's position is certain. Why don't you urgently request Empress Lü to seize the opportunity and weepingly tell the emperor: 'Ying Bu is a fierce general of the realm, skilled in using troops, now the various generals are all your majesty's former equals, to command the crown prince to lead these people is no different from making a sheep lead wolves, none will be willing to be employed, moreover if Bu hears of it, he will drum and advance west. Although your majesty is ill, force yourself to ride in the baggage cart, lie down and supervise them, the various generals will dare not not exert full effort. Although your majesty suffers, for the sake of wife and children force yourself.' Thus Lü Ze that night saw Empress Lü, Empress Lü seized the opportunity and weeping told the emperor, as the four people's intention. The emperor said: 'I only considered the brat certainly insufficient to send, so I must go myself.' Thus the emperor personally led troops east, the ministers remained to guard, all escorted to Bashang. The Marquis of Liu was ill, forced himself to rise, arrived at Quyü, saw the emperor and said: 'Your servant should follow, but illness is severe. Chu people are fierce and swift, I wish your majesty not to contend with Chu people at the spearpoint.' Thus he advised the emperor: 'Have the crown prince serve as general, oversee Guanzhong troops.' The emperor said: 'Zifang although ill, force yourself to lie down and instruct the crown prince.' At this time Shu Sun Tong served as Grand Tutor, the Marquis of Liu performed Junior Tutor duties.

sentences.zh: 漢十二年，上從擊破布軍歸，疾益甚，愈欲易太子。

translations.literal: Han year 12, the emperor returned from attacking and defeating Bu's army, illness grew worse, even more wished to change the crown prince.

sentences.zh: 留侯諫，不聽，因疾不視事。

translations.literal: The Marquis of Liu remonstrated, not listened to, thus due to illness did not handle affairs.

sentences.zh: 叔孫太傅稱說引古今，以死爭太子。

translations.literal: Grand Tutor Shu Sun cited and explained ancient and modern to contend for the crown prince to the death.

sentences.zh: 上詳許之，猶欲易之。

translations.literal: The emperor pretended to permit it, yet still wished to change him.

sentences.zh: 及燕，置酒，太子侍。

translations.literal: When feasting, set up wine, the crown prince attended.

sentences.zh: 四人從太子，年皆八十有餘，鬚眉皓白，衣冠甚偉。

translations.literal: The four people followed the crown prince, ages all over eighty, beards and eyebrows white, clothing and caps extremely magnificent.

sentences.zh: 上怪之，問曰：「彼何為者？」

translations.literal: The emperor was astonished, asked: 'Who are those?'

sentences.zh: 四人前對，各言名姓，曰東園公，角里先生，綺里季，夏黃公。

translations.literal: The four people advanced and replied, each stated name and surname: Dongyuan Gong, Jiali Xiansheng, Qili Ji, Xiahuaing Gong.

sentences.zh: 上乃大驚，曰：「吾求公數歲，公辟逃我，今公何自從吾兒游乎？」

translations.literal: The emperor then greatly astonished, said: 'I have sought you gentlemen for several years, you gentlemen avoided and fled me, now why do you gentlemen follow my son in leisure?'

sentences.zh: 四人皆曰：「陛下輕士善罵，臣等義不受辱，故恐而亡匿。

translations.literal: The four people all said: 'Your majesty lightly esteems scholars and is good at cursing, we servants righteously would not accept insult, thus feared and fled into hiding.

sentences.zh: 竊聞太子為人仁孝，恭敬愛士，天下莫不延頸欲為太子死者，故臣等來耳。」

translations.literal: We secretly heard the crown prince is humane and filial, respectful and loves scholars, the realm none do not crane necks desiring to die for the crown prince, thus we servants came.'

sentences.zh: 上曰：「煩公幸卒調護太子。」

translations.literal: The emperor said: 'I trouble you gentlemen to happily finally protect and care for the crown prince.'

Han year 12, the emperor returned from attacking and defeating Bu's army, illness grew worse, even more wished to change the crown prince. The Marquis of Liu remonstrated, not listened to, thus due to illness did not handle affairs. Grand Tutor Shu Sun cited and explained ancient and modern to contend for the crown prince to the death. The emperor pretended to permit it, yet still wished to change him. When feasting, set up wine, the crown prince attended. The four people followed the crown prince, ages all over eighty, beards and eyebrows white, clothing and caps extremely magnificent. The emperor was astonished, asked: 'Who are those?' The four people advanced and replied, each stated name and surname: Dongyuan Gong, Jiali Xiansheng, Qili Ji, Xiahuaing Gong. The emperor then greatly astonished, said: 'I have sought you gentlemen for several years, you gentlemen avoided and fled me, now why do you gentlemen follow my son in leisure?' The four people all said: 'Your majesty lightly esteems scholars and is good at cursing, we servants righteously would not accept insult, thus feared and fled into hiding. We secretly heard the crown prince is humane and filial, respectful and loves scholars, the realm none do not crane necks desiring to die for the crown prince, thus we servants came.' The emperor said: 'I trouble you gentlemen to happily finally protect and care for the crown prince.'

sentences.zh: 四人為壽已畢，趨去。

translations.literal: The four people having made toasts finished, hurried away.

sentences.zh: 上目送之，召戚夫人指示四人者曰：「我欲易之，彼四人輔之，羽翼已成，難動矣。

translations.literal: The emperor watched them depart, summoned Lady Qi and pointed to the four people saying: 'I wished to change him, those four people assist him, wings are already formed, difficult to move.

sentences.zh: 呂后真而主矣。」

translations.literal: Empress Lü is truly the master.'

sentences.zh: 戚夫人泣，上曰：「為我楚舞，吾為若楚歌。」

translations.literal: Lady Qi wept, the emperor said: 'Dance the Chu dance for me, I will sing the Chu song for you.'

sentences.zh: 歌曰：「鴻鴈高飛，一舉千里。

translations.literal: He sang: 'Wild geese fly high, one flight a thousand li.

sentences.zh: 羽翮已就，橫絕四海。

translations.literal: Feathers and wings already formed, spanning across the four seas.

sentences.zh: 橫絕四海，當可奈何！

translations.literal: Spanning across the four seas, what can be done about it!

sentences.zh: 雖有矰繳，尚安所施！」

translations.literal: Even if there are arrows and strings, where can they still be applied!'

sentences.zh: 歌數闋，戚夫人噓唏流涕，上起去，罷酒。

translations.literal: He sang several stanzas, Lady Qi sobbed and wept, the emperor rose and left, the banquet ended.

sentences.zh: 竟不易太子者，留侯本招此四人之力也。

translations.literal: In the end he did not change the crown prince—the Marquis of Liu originally summoned these four people's strength.

The four people having made toasts finished, hurried away. The emperor watched them depart, summoned Lady Qi and pointed to the four people saying: 'I wished to change him, those four people assist him, wings are already formed, difficult to move. Empress Lü is truly the master.' Lady Qi wept, the emperor said: 'Dance the Chu dance for me, I will sing the Chu song for you.' He sang: 'Wild geese fly high, one flight a thousand li. Feathers and wings already formed, spanning across the four seas. Spanning across the four seas, what can be done about it! Even if there are arrows and strings, where can they still be applied!' He sang several stanzas, Lady Qi sobbed and wept, the emperor rose and left, the banquet ended. In the end he did not change the crown prince—the Marquis of Liu originally summoned these four people's strength.

sentences.zh: 留侯從上擊代，出奇計馬邑下，及立蕭何相國，所與上從容言天下事甚眾，非天下所以存亡，故不著。

translations.literal: The Marquis of Liu followed the emperor attacking Dai, put forth extraordinary plans at Maiyi, and when establishing Xiao He as prime minister, the affairs of the realm he discussed leisurely with the emperor were very many, but they were not the realm's matters of survival and extinction, thus not recorded.

sentences.zh: 留侯乃稱曰：「家世相韓，及韓滅，不愛萬金之資，為韓報讐彊秦，天下振動。

translations.literal: The Marquis of Liu then said: 'My family for generations served as chancellors of Han, and when Han was extinguished, I did not spare ten thousand jin of wealth, to avenge Han I strongly opposed Qin, shaking the realm.

sentences.zh: 今以三寸舌為帝者師，封萬戶，位列侯，此布衣之極，於良足矣。

translations.literal: Now with three cun tongue I serve as the emperor's teacher, enfeoffed with ten thousand households, position as marquis—this is the extreme for a commoner, sufficient for Liang.

sentences.zh: 願棄人間事，欲從赤松子游耳。」

translations.literal: I wish to abandon worldly affairs, desire to follow Master Chisong in roaming.'

sentences.zh: 乃學辟穀，道引輕身。

translations.literal: Thus he studied avoiding grain, guiding and pulling to lighten the body.

sentences.zh: 會高帝崩，呂后德留侯，乃彊食之，曰：「人生一世間，如白駒過隙，何至自苦如此乎！」

translations.literal: When Gaozu passed away, Empress Lü appreciated the Marquis of Liu, thus forced him to eat, saying: 'A person's life in the world is like a white colt passing through a crack, why go so far as to torment yourself like this!'

sentences.zh: 留侯不得已，彊聽而食。

translations.literal: The Marquis of Liu had no choice, strongly listened and ate.

The Marquis of Liu followed the emperor attacking Dai, put forth extraordinary plans at Maiyi, and when establishing Xiao He as prime minister, the affairs of the realm he discussed leisurely with the emperor were very many, but they were not the realm's matters of survival and extinction, thus not recorded. The Marquis of Liu then said: 'My family for generations served as chancellors of Han, and when Han was extinguished, I did not spare ten thousand jin of wealth, to avenge Han I strongly opposed Qin, shaking the realm. Now with three cun tongue I serve as the emperor's teacher, enfeoffed with ten thousand households, position as marquis—this is the extreme for a commoner, sufficient for Liang. I wish to abandon worldly affairs, desire to follow Master Chisong in roaming.' Thus he studied avoiding grain, guiding and pulling to lighten the body. When Gaozu passed away, Empress Lü appreciated the Marquis of Liu, thus forced him to eat, saying: 'A person's life in the world is like a white colt passing through a crack, why go so far as to torment yourself like this!' The Marquis of Liu had no choice, strongly listened and ate.

sentences.zh: 後八年卒，謚為文成侯。

translations.literal: Eight years later he died, given the posthumous title Marquis Wen Cheng.

sentences.zh: 子不疑代侯。

translations.literal: His son Buyi succeeded as marquis.
Eight years later he died, given the posthumous title Marquis Wen Cheng. His son Buyi succeeded as marquis.

sentences.zh: 子房始所見下邳圯上老父與太公書者，後十三年從高帝過濟北，果見穀城山下黃石，取而葆祠之。

translations.literal: Zifang at first saw the old man on the Xiapi bridge who gave him the Taigong book—thirteen years later following Gaozu passing Jibei, indeed saw the yellow stone under Gucheng Mountain, took it and treasured and sacrificed to it.

sentences.zh: 留侯死，并葬黃石（冢）。

translations.literal: When the Marquis of Liu died, he was buried together with the yellow stone tomb.

sentences.zh: 每上冢伏臘，祠黃石。

translations.literal: Every time ascending the tomb at winter sacrifices, he sacrificed to the yellow stone.

Zifang at first saw the old man on the Xiapi bridge who gave him the Taigong book—thirteen years later following Gaozu passing Jibei, indeed saw the yellow stone under Gucheng Mountain, took it and treasured and sacrificed to it. When the Marquis of Liu died, he was buried together with the yellow stone tomb. Every time ascending the tomb at winter sacrifices, he sacrificed to the yellow stone.

sentences.zh: 留侯不疑，孝文帝五年坐不敬，國除。

translations.literal: The Marquis of Liu Buyi, in Emperor Wen year 5, was convicted of disrespect, the state abolished.
The Marquis of Liu Buyi, in Emperor Wen year 5, was convicted of disrespect, the state abolished.

sentences.zh: 太史公曰：學者多言無鬼神，然言有物。

translations.literal: The Grand Historian says: Scholars mostly say there are no ghosts and spirits, yet they speak of having things.

sentences.zh: 至如留侯所見老父予書，亦可怪矣。

translations.literal: As for the Marquis of Liu seeing the old man give the book, it can also be considered strange.

sentences.zh: 高祖離困者數矣，而留侯常有功力焉，豈可謂非天乎？

translations.literal: Gaozu departed from difficulties several times, yet the Marquis of Liu constantly had meritorious strength—how can this not be called heaven?

sentences.zh: 上曰：「夫運籌筴帷帳之中，決勝千里外，吾不如子房。」

translations.literal: The emperor said: 'Planning strategies within the tent, deciding victories a thousand li away—I am not equal to Zifang.'

sentences.zh: 余以為其人計魁梧奇偉，至見其圖，狀貌如婦人好女。

translations.literal: I considered this person in planning to be stalwart and extraordinary, until seeing his portrait, his appearance was like a woman or beautiful girl.

sentences.zh: 蓋孔子曰：「以貌取人，失之子羽。」

translations.literal: As Confucius said: 'To take people by appearance loses Zi Yu.'

sentences.zh: 留侯亦云。

translations.literal: The Marquis of Liu was also thus.

The Grand Historian says: Scholars mostly say there are no ghosts and spirits, yet they speak of having things. As for the Marquis of Liu seeing the old man give the book, it can also be considered strange. Gaozu departed from difficulties several times, yet the Marquis of Liu constantly had meritorious strength—how can this not be called heaven? The emperor said: 'Planning strategies within the tent, deciding victories a thousand li away—I am not equal to Zifang.' I considered this person in planning to be stalwart and extraordinary, until seeing his portrait, his appearance was like a woman or beautiful girl. As Confucius said: 'To take people by appearance loses Zi Yu.' The Marquis of Liu was also thus.
